Article.ArticleTitle: Effect of exogenous catechin on alleviating O<sub>3</sub> stress: The role of catechin-quinone in lipid peroxidation, salicylic acid, chlorophyll content, and antioxidant enzymes of Zamioculcas zamiifolia.

AbstractText: Ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) can cause oxidative stress in plants and humans. Catechin is an antioxidant that enriches tea and can probably increase O<sub>3</sub> tolerance in plants. To investigate the mechanism of catechin to alleviate O<sub>3</sub> stress in plants, Zamiocalcus zamiifolia (an efficient plant for O<sub>3</sub> phytoremediation) was sprayed with 5 mM catechin and was used to expose O<sub>3</sub> (150-250) under long-term operation (10 cycles). We investigated whether exogenous catechin could enhance O<sub>3</sub> removal and alleviate O<sub>3</sub> stress through a balanced redox state in plants. Z. zamiifolia sprayed with catechin exhibited higher O<sub>3</sub> removal (80.27±3.12%), than Z. zamiifolia without catechin (50.03±2.68%). O<sub>3</sub> in the range of 150-250 ppb led to stress in plants, as shown by an increased malondialdehyde content (MDA) and salicylic acid (SA). Whereas under the presence of O<sub>3</sub>, exogenous catechin could maintain the MDA content and inhibit SA accumulation. Under Z. zamiifolia+catechin+O<sub>3</sub> conditions, catechin reacted with O<sub>3</sub>, which led to the formation of catechin-quinone. The formation of catechin-quinone was confirmed by the depletion of reduced glutathione content (GSH). This catechin-quinone could induce GST and APX genes that are up-regulated approximately 35- and 5-fold, respectively. Hence, Z. zamiifolia+catechin+O<sub>3</sub> conditions had higher performance for coping with oxidative stress than did Z. zamiifolia+O<sub>3</sub> conditions. This evidence demonstrates that catechin could enhance O<sub>3</sub> removal through a balanced redox state in plant cells. Finally, the application of tea extract for enhanced O<sub>3</sub> removal is also shown in this study.
